question: Second Batch (2024-8-8) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 1 Frontal sinus drains into the …....
explanation: The frontal sinus drains into the middle meatus through the frontonasal duct, which is part of the semilunar hiatus.

question: Second Batch (2024-8-8) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 2 Which bone is located in the nasal septum?
explanation: The vomer is one of the bones forming the nasal septum, along with the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid bone and cartilage.

question: Second Batch (2024-8-8) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 3 General sensation of the nasal cavity is carried by …
explanation: The general sensory innervation of the nasal cavity is provided by branches of the trigeminal nerve (CN V), mainly the maxillary (V2) and ophthalmic (V1) divisions.

question: Second Batch (2024-8-8) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 4 Which one is a branch of the maxillary artery?
explanation: The sphenopalatine artery is a major branch of the maxillary artery and supplies the nasal cavity.

question: Second Batch (2024-8-8) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 5 Anterior region of the medial wall of the nasal cavity is the major site of nose bleeding or epistaxis. Kiesselbach plexus in this area is formed by all of the following arteries, EXCEPT:
explanation: The anterior choroidal artery is not part of Kiesselbach’s plexus.

question: Second Batch (2024-8-8) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 6 Pharyngeal raphe is formed by …
explanation: The pharyngeal raphe is formed by the midline insertion of the pharyngeal constrictor muscles.

question: Second Batch (2024-8-8) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 7 Galen anastomosis under piriform recess is formed by …
options: Internal laryngeal and recurrent laryngeal nerves
answerText: Internal laryngeal and recurrent laryngeal nerves
explanation: Galen’s anastomosis is formed by the internal and recurrent laryngeal nerves and is located beneath the piriform recess.

question: Second Batch (2024-8-8) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 8 Articular facet on the lateral surface of the cricoid cartilage is for articulation of the …
options: Inferior horn of the thyroid cartilage
Superior horn of the thyroid cartilage
answerText: Inferior horn of the thyroid cartilage
explanation: The cricoid cartilage articulates with the inferior horn of the thyroid cartilage, allowing for movement of the larynx.

question: Second Batch (2024-8-8) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 9 Which structure is formed by the superior free border of the conus elasticus?
explanation: The vocal ligament is formed by the superior free border of the conus elasticus and plays a role in sound production.

question: Second Batch (2024-8-8) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 10 Where is the rima glottidis?
options: Between the epiglottis and vocal folds
explanation: The rima glottidis is the opening between the true vocal folds and is involved in phonation and airway regulation.

question: Second Batch (2024-8-8) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 11 Which muscle is innervated by the external laryngeal nerve?
explanation: The cricothyroid muscle is innervated by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve and functions to tense the vocal cords.

question: Second Batch (2024-8-8) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 12 Which nerve supplies sensory innervation of the larynx from the laryngeal inlet to the vocal folds?
explanation: The internal laryngeal nerve provides sensory innervation from the laryngeal inlet to the vocal cords.

question: Second Batch (2024-8-8) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 13 Bifurcation of the trachea is at the level of:
explanation: The trachea bifurcates at the level of the sternal angle (T4-T5 vertebral level) into the right and left main bronchi.

question: Second Batch (2024-8-8) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 14 Which one is located between the neck of the first rib and the apex of the lung?
explanation: The cervicothoracic ganglion (stellate ganglion) is found near the neck of the first rib and apex of the lung.

question: Second Batch (2024-8-8) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 15 The mediastinal pleura is innervated by …
explanation: The phrenic nerve innervates the mediastinal pleura and the pericardium.

question: Second Batch (2024-8-8) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 16 Where is the inferior border of the lung in the mid-axillary line?
explanation: The inferior border of the lung is at the 8th rib along the mid-axillary line.

question: Second Batch (2024-8-8) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 17 Which structure has a relationship with the superior part of the hilum of the right lung?
explanation: The arch of the azygos vein arches over the superior part of the right lung hilum before emptying into the superior vena cava.

question: Second Batch (2024-8-8) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 18 Where is the location of the pharyngeal tonsil?
explanation: The pharyngeal tonsil (adenoids) is located on the roof and posterior wall of the nasopharynx.

question: Second Batch (2024-8-8) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 19 Which bone on the lateral wall of the nasal cavity is a separate bone of the facial skeleton?
explanation: The inferior nasal concha is a separate bone, while the middle and superior conchae are part of the ethmoid bone.

question: Second Batch (2024-8-8) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 20 The laryngeal prominence is formed by …
explanation: The laryngeal prominence (Adam’s apple) is formed by the thyroid cartilage in the larynx.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 1 Which laryngeal muscle is innervated by external laryngeal nerve?
explanation: The external laryngeal nerve innervates only the cricothyroid muscle, which tenses the vocal cords.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 2 Which type of epithelium is in the maxillary sinus?
explanation: The maxillary sinus is lined by pseudostratified columnar epithelium with cilia, typical of respiratory epithelium.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 3 Vocal folds are lined by which type of the epithelium?
explanation: Vocal folds are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium to withstand mechanical stress.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 4 Where is the location of Galen anastomosis?
explanation: Galen anastomosis is a connection between the internal and recurrent laryngeal nerves located near the piriform recess.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 5 In which part of the tracheobronchial tree are there more Clara’s cells?
explanation: Clara cells, which secrete surfactant-like protein, are more abundant in the respiratory bronchioles.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 6 After 30 years smoking in the 60-year-old man epithelium of the trachea becomes squamous stratified, what is the name of this transition?
explanation: Metaplasia is the reversible change of one epithelial type to another due to chronic irritation, like smoking.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 7 Which structures pass through thyrohyoid membrane?
options: Recurrent laryngeal nerve and inferior thyroid artery
External laryngeal nerve and superior thyroid vein
Internal laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal artery
Ansa cervicalis and inferior laryngeal artery
answerText: Internal laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal artery
explanation: The internal laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal artery pierce the thyrohyoid membrane to supply the larynx.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 8 Which one has simple columnar epithelium, without Goblet cells and lack of glands and cartilage?
explanation: Terminal bronchioles are lined with simple columnar epithelium without goblet cells, glands, or cartilage.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 9 In the structure of which laryngeal cartilage are there hyaline and elastic cartilages?
explanation: The arytenoid cartilage has a hyaline base and elastic apex and processes.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 10 In the mid axillary line inferior border of the pleura is at the level of which rib?
explanation: In the mid-axillary line, the pleura extends down to the 10th rib.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 11 Which cell in the respiratory epithelium is a stem cell that repairs other cells?
explanation: Basal cells serve as stem cells, regenerating other epithelial cells.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 12 Right bronchiolar artery is a branch of which one?
explanation: The right bronchial artery commonly arises from the 3rd right posterior intercostal artery.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 13 Which one is the first stage in development of the lung?
explanation: The pseudoglandular stage is the earliest phase of lung development (weeks 5-17).

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 14 Where is the location of suprapleural (Sibson’s) membrane?
options: Between first rib and transverse process of the C7
Above the apex of the heart
answerText: Between first rib and transverse process of the C7
explanation: Sibson’s membrane reinforces the pleura over the apex of the lung, attached to the first rib and C7 transverse process.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 15 Which structure is located between neck of the first rib and apex of the lung?
explanation: The stellate ganglion is found between the neck of the first rib and the apex of the lung.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 16 Why inhaled foreign bodies tend to lodge more frequently on the right main bronchus than on the left?
explanation: The right main bronchus is shorter, wider, and more vertical than the left, favoring foreign body entry.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 17 Which one is called eparterial bronchus?
options: Inferior lobar bronchus on the right side
Superior lobar bronchus on the left side
Superior lobar bronchus on the right side
answerText: Superior lobar bronchus on the right side
explanation: The superior lobar bronchus on the right is termed “eparterial” as it passes above the pulmonary artery.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 18 Where is the location of pharyngeal tonsil?
explanation: The pharyngeal tonsil is located on the superior posterior wall of the nasopharynx.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 19 Which one is between nasopharynx and oropharynx?
explanation: The soft palate separates the nasopharynx from the oropharynx.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 20 Which one is epithelium of the nasopharynx?
explanation: The nasopharynx is lined with pseudostratified columnar epithelium with cilia.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 21 Which structure is related to the creation of the nasal cycle?
explanation: The swell body is involved in regulating airflow alternately between nasal cavities, causing the nasal cycle.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 22 Which paranasal sinus drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess?
explanation: The sphenoid sinus drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 23 Superior free border of the conus elasticus makes which one?
explanation: The upper free edge of the conus elasticus forms the vocal ligament.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 24 Which nerve innervates mucosa of the larynx superior to vocal folds?
explanation: The internal laryngeal nerve innervates the mucosa above the vocal folds.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 25 Which one is a branch of the ophthalmic artery?
explanation: The anterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the ophthalmic artery.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 26 When paranasal sinuses reach maximum size?
explanation: Paranasal sinuses enlarge significantly and reach their maximum size at puberty.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 27 Which part of the pleura is innervated by phrenic nerve?
explanation: The phrenic nerve supplies the mediastinal pleura and the central part of the diaphragmatic pleura.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 28 Which cell is called dust cell?
explanation: Dust cells are alveolar macrophages responsible for cleaning debris in the alveoli.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 29 Which one is the origin of laryngeal cartilages?
explanation: Laryngeal cartilages develop from the 4th and 6th pharyngeal arches.

question: First Batch (2023-10-28) Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 30 Which congenital malformation is related to incomplete formation of the tracheoesophageal septum?
explanation: Esophageal atresia results from incomplete formation of the tracheoesophageal septum during development.
